elements.text:
Dear Julia users,
I am using a Finite element package JuAFEM to run some simple FEM elasticity problems. I am facing a problem generating the vtk file. It says 'dh' not defined but in the code, dh is already defined. I am quite new to Julia. Please help. Below is the code

messages.text:
```using JuAFEM
using BlockArrays, SparseArrays, LinearAlgebra

   corners = [Vec{2}((0.0,  0.0)),
              Vec{2}((1.0, 0.0)),
              Vec{2}((1.0, 1.0)),
              Vec{2}((0.0, 1.0))]
   grid = generate_grid(QuadraticQuadrilateral, (1, 1), corners);
   

#Interpolation & Quadrature rule
function create_values(interpolation_u)
   # quadrature rules
   qr     = QuadratureRule{2,RefCube}(3)
   face_qr = QuadratureRule{1,RefCube}(3)

   # geometric interpolation
   interpolation_geom = Lagrange{2,RefCube,2}()

   # cell and facevalues for u
   cellvalues_u = CellVectorValues(qr, interpolation_u, interpolation_geom)
   facevalues_u = FaceVectorValues(face_qr, interpolation_u, interpolation_geom)
   return cellvalues_u, facevalues_u
end;


function create_dofhandler(grid, ipu)
   dh = DofHandler(grid)
   push!(dh, :u, 2, ipu) # displacement
   close!(dh)
   return dh
end;

function create_bc(dh)
   dbc = ConstraintHandler(dh)

   add!(dbc, Dirichlet(:u, getfaceset(dh.grid, "bottom"), (x,t) -> 0.0, [2]))
   add!(dbc, Dirichlet(:u, getfaceset(dh.grid, "left") , (x,t) -> 0.0, [1]))
   close!(dbc)
   t = 0.0
   update!(dbc, t)
   return dbc
end;

function create_stiffness(::Val{dim}) where {dim}
   E = 1.0
   ν = 0.3
   λ = E*ν / ((1+ν) * (1 - 2ν))
   μ = E / (2(1+ν))
   δ(i,j) = i == j ? 1.0 : 0.0
   g(i,j,k,l) = λ*δ(i,j)*δ(k,l) + μ*(δ(i,k)*δ(j,l) + δ(i,l)*δ(j,k))
   C = SymmetricTensor{4, dim}(g);
   return C
end;

function doassemble(cellvalues_u::CellVectorValues{dim},
                   facevalues_u::FaceVectorValues{dim}, K::SparseMatrixCSC, grid::Grid,
                   dh::DofHandler) where {dim}

   f = zeros(ndofs(dh))
   assembler = start_assemble(K, f)
   nu = getnbasefunctions(cellvalues_u)

   fe = PseudoBlockArray(zeros(nu), [nu]) # local force vector
   ke = PseudoBlockArray(zeros(nu , nu), [nu], [nu]) # local stiffness matrix

   # traction vector
   t = Vec{2}((1.0, 0.0))
   # cache ɛdev outside the element routine to avoid some unnecessary allocations

   for cell in CellIterator(dh)
       fill!(ke, 0)
       fill!(fe, 0)
       assemble_up!(ke, fe, cell, cellvalues_u, facevalues_u, grid, t)
       assemble!(assembler, celldofs(cell), fe, ke)
   end

   return K, f
end;

function assemble_up!(Ke, fe, cell, cellvalues_u, facevalues_u, grid, t)

   n_basefuncs_u = getnbasefunctions(cellvalues_u)
   reinit!(cellvalues_u, cell)
   C = create_stiffness(Val(2))

    @inbounds for q_point in 1:getnquadpoints(cellvalues_u) # loop over quadrature points
       dΩ = getdetJdV(cellvalues_u, q_point)
       for i in 1:n_basefuncs_u # loop over number of ansatz functions
           BuT = symmetric(shape_gradient(cellvalues_u, q_point, i))
           for j in 1:i 
               Bu = symmetric(shape_gradient(cellvalues_u, q_point, j))
               Ke[i, j] += BuT ⊡ C ⊡ Bu * dΩ 
           end
       end
   end
symmetrize_lower!(Ke)

   
   @inbounds for face in 1:nfaces(cell)
       if onboundary(cell, face) && (cellid(cell), face) ∈ getfaceset(grid, "right")
           reinit!(facevalues_u, cell, face)
           for q_point in 1:getnquadpoints(facevalues_u)
               dΓ = getdetJdV(facevalues_u, q_point)
               for i in 1:n_basefuncs_u
                   δu = shape_value(facevalues_u, q_point, i)
                   fe[i] += (δu ⋅ t) * dΓ
               end
           end
       end
   end
end

function symmetrize_lower!(K)
   for i in 1:size(K,1)
       for j in i+1:size(K,1)
           K[i,j] = K[j,i]
       end
   end
end;



function solve(interpolation_u)

   # grid, dofhandler, boundary condition
   
   dh = create_dofhandler(grid, interpolation_u)
   dbc = create_bc(dh)

   # cellvalues
   cellvalues_u, facevalues_u = create_values(interpolation_u)

   # assembly and solve
   K = create_sparsity_pattern(dh);
   K, f = doassemble(cellvalues_u, facevalues_u, K, grid, dh);
   apply!(K, f, dbc)
   u = Symmetric(K) \ f;
end


quadratic = Lagrange{2,RefCube,2}()
u = solve(quadratic)

println(typeof(u))
println(u)
vtk_grid("sample grid", dh) do vtk
   vtk_point_data(vtk,dh , u)
end```

using JuAFEM
```using BlockArrays, SparseArrays, LinearAlgebra, Tensors

grid1 = generate_grid(QuadraticQuadrilateral,(10,10), Vec{2}((0.0,4.5)), Vec{2}((0.5,4.5)), Vec{2}((0.5,5.0)), Vec{2}((0.0,5.0)))
grid2 = generate_grid(QuadraticQuadrilateral,(10,10), Vec{2}((0.0,0.0)), Vec{2}((5.0,0.0)), Vec{2}((0.5,4.5)), Vec{2}((0.0,4.5)))
grid3 = generate_grid(QuadraticQuadrilateral,(10,10), Vec{2}((0.5,4.5)), Vec{2}((5.0,0.0)), Vec{2}((5.0,5.0)), Vec{2}((0.5,5.0)))

function merge_grids(grid1::Grid{dim,CellType}, grid2::Grid{dim,CellType}; tol=0.0001) where {N, dim, CellType <: Cell{<:Any, N}}
    cells′ = copy(grid1.cells)
    nodes′ = copy(grid1.nodes)
    nodemap = Dict{Int,Int}()
    next = getnnodes(grid1) + 1
    for (i2, n2) in enumerate(grid2.nodes)
        found = false
        for (i1, n1) in enumerate(grid1.nodes)
            if norm(n1.x - n2.x) < tol
                nodemap[i2] = i1
                found = true
                break
            end
        end
        if !found
            push!(nodes′, n2)
            nodemap[i2] = next
            next += 1
        end
    end
    for c in grid2.cells
        t = ntuple(N) do i
            return nodemap[c.nodes[i]]
        end
        cell′ = CellType(t)
        push!(cells′, cell′)
    end
    return Grid(cells′, nodes′)
end

merge_grids(grid1::G, grid2::G, grids::G...) where G <: Grid =
    merge_grids(merge_grids(grid1, grid2), grids...)

 grid = merge_grids(grid1,grid2, grid3)```

Hello all. I've been trying to use `LsqFit` to fit a hyperbolic tangent function to some data about terminal velocity in free fall. Using SciPy's `curve_fit` function, it seems to work fine. However, in Julia, it's nowhere near the correct fit.
Here's the function I've written to fit the curve -
```function fit_terminal_velocity(data::CSV.File)
	# Create base model with random initial parameters
	p0 = rand(2)
	model(t, p) = p[1] .* tanh.(p[2]/p[1] .* t)
	
	# We are fitting v(t), so lets get those values
	# We also want to go from t = 0 to t = t_max
	t = data.t .- minimum(data.t)
	y = data.y
	
	v  = diff(y) ./ diff(t)
	tv = t[1:end-1]
	
	
	fitted_model = lsqfit.curve_fit(model, v, tv, p0)
	
	return fitted_model, model
end```
And it gives
```p[1] = -1.04293e-10
p[2] = 0.00917912```
Whereas Python gives `p = [-623.23056677, -319.5100746 ]` , which fit the model correctly. For reference, the code in python is
```f = lambda t, g, vt : vt * np.tanh(g/vt * t)
popts, pcov = curve_fit(f, t[1:], v)```
Where `curve_fit` is `scipy.optimize.curve_fit`.

I think it may be something to do with the fact that LsqFit requires `p0` but SciPy doesn't? I would really appreciate if anybody can help me figure out why curve fitting isn't working in Julia properly. Thank you so much!

using Clang.LibClang.Clang_jll
# LIBCLANG_HEADERS are those headers to be wrapped.

            output_file = joinpath(@__DIR__, "libpcap_api.jl"),
            common_file = joinpath(@__DIR__, "libpcap_common.jl"),
            clang_includes = vcat(LIBPCAP_INCLUDE, CLANG_INCLUDE),
            clang_args = ["-I", joinpath(LIBPCAP_INCLUDE, "..")],
